awd_titl_txt: Augmented Tube Models for Blends of Star and Linear Polymers
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports computational research and education into the development of fast and accurate models of flow behavior in polymers. Properties of synthetic polymers can be tuned by engineering their molecular structure. This allows polymers to be used in a variety of applications ranging from packaging to automobiles, and from fabrics to surgical sutures. Polymers are typically processed in the liquid or melt state, where the molecular structure strongly influences flow properties. This relationship between molecular structure and flow properties is often studied using a theory called the tube model. 

Failures of the standard tube model can be traced to the manner in which it simplifies "multibody interactions" between polymer molecules. These interactions are more accurately described by a simulation model called the slip link model, which is unfortunately computationally costly. This project seeks to combine the strength of tube model (speed) with that of the slip link model (accuracy) through the development of augmented tube models. If successful, this research will provide a template for blending theories and simulations, which is expected have far reaching consequences for materials characterization, even outside the polymer industry.

The award also supports the education of minority students at Florida State University by providing modern training in materials modeling, Markov chain Monte Carlo, and statistical analysis. The software and datasets developed by the research team will be made publicly available.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports computational research and education into the development of fast and accurate models of flow behavior in polymers. The tube model is a popular mean-field theory for entangled polymer melts. Unfortunately, it fails consistently even for relatively simple systems like binary blends of monodisperse polymers with widely separated relaxation times. On the other hand, different slip link models, all of which explicitly treat entanglements between chains as slip links, are remarkably successful for such systems. This is primarily due to the different treatment of a relaxation mechanism called constraint release, in the two models. In slip link models, the description of constraint release is "natural", while it can be complicated, and still inaccurate, in the tube model. A drawback of slip link models is their computational cost. This project seeks to combine the strength of tube models (speed) with that of the slip link models (natural and accurate representation of constraint release). The overarching research objectives are (i) to explore the development of augmented tube models, which combine these strengths, and (ii) to test these augmented models on the computationally intensive inverse problem of inferring the composition of a polymer mixture from experimental measurements of rheology. 

The award supports the development of a fast slip link model called ecoSLM, and its validation, using binary blends of star and linear polymers. Research activities to service the overall objectives are broken down into four specific tasks: (i) validating the ecoSLM against all available experimental data on linear-linear, star-linear, and star-star blends, (ii) using the validated ecoSLM to map out the design space to help identify regions where the tube model fails, (iii) developing augmented tube model, which uses ecoSLM to guide the tube model to the correct physics/parameters, and (iv) to use these augmented tube models for inverse modeling.

The project explores the augmentation of a mean-field theory with a stochastic simulation model, ecoSLM, in order to combine speed with accuracy. If successful, it can provide a template for other problems in materials science that seek to combine a mean-field theory with simple simulation models. Using a Bayesian framework for inverse modeling, this can have far reaching implications for materials characterization, even outside the polymer industry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Understanding and predicting the dynamics of polymers is industrially important and scientifically fascinating. Calculations using theory are quick, but inaccurate. Molecular models and simulations are accurate, but take too long. In this project, a new model called ecoSLM was built, and applied to mixtures of linear and branched polymers - a class of materials for which theoretical predictions are least accurate. Over the course of the project, we demonstrated that ecoSLM offers a compelling tradeoff between accuracy and speed (see image F1). 

INTELLECTUAL MERITS

We validated the model by comparing its predictions with experiments. ecoSLM can quantitatively describe existing data on blends of linear and star polymers (see image F2). This gave us the confidence to venture beyond, and uncover new physics in systems such as certain star-linear blends that are beyond the reach of any other simulation method, e.g. star-linear blends, where the viscosity of the linear component is greater than the star component (see image F3). Due to the simplicity of ecoSLM, its results can often be interpreted through the lens of the so-called tube theory.

Molecular models like ecoSLM provide a physics-based link between polymer structure and properties. From an industrial standpoint, an important application is rational design, which tries to answer the question "If I want this set of desirable properties, what material should I synthesize?" This leads to a so-called inverse problem, which requires us to run the model thousands to millions of times. Despite its speed, this is too expensive even for ecoSLM. . We developed a method for inversion that uses an inexpensive surrogate model which assimilates or learns the patterns produced by original model (see image F4).

BROADER IMPACTS

Polyolefins, which are the primary materials targeted in this work, are by far the largest class of synthetic polymers produced by volume. This enormous scale implies that even small improvements in characterization have the potential for substantial industrial impact.

Some of the algorithms developed for the project can be applied to other materials characterization and design problems, where molecular models exist, but are computationally expensive to evaluate. Software developed over the course of the project can be downloaded freely. It has already found use in applications beyond the particular systems for which it was developed (see image F5).

Furthermore, personnel (four students) trained over the course of this project helped develop more talent in scientific machine learning, which combines traditional computational science modeling of scientific phenomena with data-driven methodologies.


Last Modified: 06/16/2022
Modified by: Sachin A Shanbhag

Images (1 of )
  • ecoSLM offers a compelling tradeoff between accuracy and speed compared to theory or existing molecular models and simulations.
    Sachin Shanbhag
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Sachin A Shanbhag
    F1: Schematic diagram of accuracy and speed
  • We compared ecoSLM simulations on star-linear blends with experimental data on three datasets: (i) S88[Struglinski et al., 1988], (ii) S14 [Shivokhin et al. 2014.], and (iii) D16 [Desai et al., 2016]
    Sachin Shanbhag
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Sachin A Shanbhag
    Viscosity of Star-Linear Blends
  • Based on experiments, a region (red) of design space where nonmonotonic dependence of relaxation time can be observed was identified. ecoSLM confirmed this, and also identified another regime (gray), where this phenomenon disappears.
    Sachin Shanbhag
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Sachin A Shanbhag
    F3: Star-linear blend nonmonotonic viscosity
  • The true MWD is shown by the solid red line. The MWDscorresponding to the average sample obtained with (a) the true molecular model (TDD-DR), and (b) the surrogate model (GP-SM-53) are shown, together with the uncertainty.
    Sachin Shanbhag
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Sachin A Shanbhag
    F4: Inversion of molecular weight distribution
  • An open-source software called pyReSpect was released to extract the relaxation spectrum from linear viscoelasticity.
    Sachin Shanbhag
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Sachin A Shanbhag
    F5: pyReSpect
